Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The role of tongue position in voicing contrasts in cross-linguistic contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are many factors that cause speakers of multiple languages to be in contact in the United States. Many Americans are natively bilingual or multilingual speakers and many others study various languages as a second language. Also, speakers of different languages from other countries learn English when they come to the US. An important component of learning and using multiple languages is establishing the sound categories that are appropriate to each of the languages. Many languages use similar sounds, but how they are actually pronounced varies from language to language. This research will contribute to our understanding of how speakers of different languages facilitate their language's sound contrasts through dynamic tongue movement. By understanding the difference in tongue dynamics across languages, second language learners, instructors, and speech therapists can have a more detailed understanding of the phonetic differences between one's native language and target language, even when the two seem phonologically similar.

This research focuses on how similar sounds across languages are articulated differently. For example, the consonant at the beginning of the word 'dog' in English ('d'), is similar to 'd' in Portuguese (e.g. 'dados'), but differences in the production of 'd' emerge when the two languages are examined closely. Portuguese 'd' is phonated, which means the vocal folds are vibrating while the tongue is constricted in the mouth to produce this sound, whereas English 'd' is often not phonated during tongue constriction. While the vibration of the vocal folds can be inferred through acoustic analysis, this current research asks what articulatory adjustments may be used in order to produce the acoustic differences that distinguish the production of similar sounds across languages. Articulations in the mouth can be observed using ultrasound imaging, revealing how the tongue moves to adjust the shape of the mouth. For example, we can see how the tongue position of English 'd' is different from that of Portuguese 'd', which may help us understand how phonation is achieved within this dynamic system. This study first focuses on how the phonetic target of voiced stops (such as the 'd' of English or Portuguese) in different languages compares acoustically and articulatorily, and second, how tongue position reflects different systems of voicing contrast by comparing six different languages: English, German, (Brazilian) Portuguese, Korean, Hindi, and Thai. The articulatory, acoustic and theoretical methods used to address this issue can be extended beyond the six languages covered in this study. The collective results in different languages can be applied to second language learning, with a more detailed account of consonant articulation across languages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to contribute to our understanding of how similar sounds across languages are articulated differently. The consonant at the beginning of the word ‘dog’ in English (‘d’), is similar to ‘d’ in Spanish (e.g. ‘dos’), but differences in the production of ‘d’ are evident when the two languages are examined closely. Spanish ‘d’ is phonated, which means the vocal cords are vibrating while the tongue is constricted in the mouth to produce this sound, whereas English ‘d’ is not phonated during tongue constriction. The current study explored how tongue position is employed to produce voiced sounds (for example, English “[b]ig”, “[d]eal”, “[g]eek”) and voiceless sounds (“[p]ig”, “[t]eal”, “[k]ey”) in utterance-initial position in different languages. More specifically, this study aims to answer the question of whether the contrast of voiced “b, d, g” vs. voiceless “p, t, k” correlates with tongue position in each language. In this project, articulatory and acoustic data were analyzed, and different mental representations for the sounds of these languages were proposed to explain results.

This study used ultrasound imaging to collect tongue shape images, and data from 40 speakers of five different languages were studied in depth (English, Brazilian Portuguese, German, Hindi, and Thai). While ultrasound imaging has been used to study the movements of the tongue tip and blade during speech, this study is the first to demonstrate that this methodology can also be used to detect tongue root advancement for voicing contrasts in some languages.

In languages with binary voicing contrasts, there is typically a set of “voiced” stops and a corresponding set of “voiceless” stops. In utterance-initial position, American English and German stops /b, d, g/ (e.g. English “[b]ig”, “[d]eal”, “[g]eek”) are often not phonated and corresponding voiceless stops /p, t, k/ are produced with aspiration. The Brazilian Portuguese stops /b, d, g/ (e.g. “[b]anko”, “[d]ados”, “[g]atas”) are realized with phonation while /p, t, k/ are not phonated. In these languages with a binary voicing contrast, results show a clear distinction between /b, d, g/ and /p, t, k/ with regard to tongue position. Even without phonation, the tongue position is more fronted for /b, d, g/ in comparison to /p, t, k/ in English and German. The difference in tongue position reflects the sound contrasts in these languages. In languages with multiple voicing contrasts exceeding a binary distinction, such as Thai with a three-way voicing contrast and Hindi with a four-way voicing contrast, data show that voiced stops are also produced with more tongue root advancement than voiceless stops. Overall, in all the languages in this study, tongue root advancement was used to make a distinction between voiced and voiceless stops.

Consonant voicing contrasts have been studied extensively both in phonetics and phonology, but there is relatively sparse substantial articulatory evidence on utterance-initial stop voicing, especially in cross-linguistic contexts. Articulatory evidence can give us insight into the appropriate representation that best characterizes voicing specification. This project adds to our knowledge of how phonetic detail and phonological abstraction can be related, focusing on articulatory data. In addition to contributing to phonetic science, this research can be used to inform theories of abstract representations of laryngeal contrasts across languages.

 

Broader impacts

Second language instructors can use the ultrasound results collected in this project to demonstrate to students how different languages have a variety of acoustic and articulatory implementations for seemingly similar sounds. Also, having detailed phonetic data on different languages will eventually enhance the understanding of different languages found in the United States and around the world.
